awd_titl_txt: NSF Convergence Accelerator Track H: Leveraging Human-Centered AI Microtransit to Ameliorate Spatiotemporal Mismatch between Housing and Employment for Persons with Disabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
Persons with disabilities (PWD) have historically faced significant employment challenges mainly due to lack of transportation to employment-related Points of Interest (ePOIs) such as work, education, and training locations. Paratransit services that provide door-to-door and curb-to-curb services could alleviate the first/last mile problem. However, they often require submitting pick-up requests a few days to a few weeks in advance, which is not flexible enough to handle more urgent requests to arrive at ePOIs on time. A main reason for such temporal lags is the lack of accessible technology that helps make complex yet prompt decisions for the determination of pick-up/drop-off location, routing, scheduling, and re-routing. This project promotes disability inclusion in workplaces by enhancing the availability and reliability of paratransit services. Specifically, our vision is to deliver an open-source human-centered Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology that aids microtransit services to determine when and where to pick up/drop off PWD, and incorporates near real-time routing algorithms to serve more urgent PWD requests between residential and ePOI-rich regions.
 
This project will be built on the already established strong collaboration among several organizations operating in the Metro Detroit Area, including paratransit service providers, disability research institutions, workforce development institutions, outreach communication services, and Wayne State University. Specifically, in this project we plan to: (1) Organize outreach activities, focus groups, and workshops to involve more organizations, have a convergent stakeholder discussion to better understand their needs, how best to provide near real-time paratransit services to meet identified needs, and identify data and ePOIs for testing; (2) Study inflow and outflow of paratransit service demand across regions and accessibility for PWD in the identified service area; (3) Create measurement tools for success of our prototype for each stakeholder type (user, service provider, employers). The data and measurement tools generated by this project will shape the development and design of the proposed technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
1. We engaged with members of the public, transportation representatives, employment specialists, and software-as-a-service (SaaS) providers through two rounds of interviews and surveys. The first round provided insights into transportation challenges, helping to guide the focus for the next phase. The second round included proof-of-concept online surveys to evaluate their usefulness for riders and transit stakeholders.

2. We created a prototype system to automatically make pedestrian maps designed for wheelchair users. It uses a powerful computer vision model called the Segment Anything Model (SAM). This model was trained using a massive collection of high-quality images, allowing it to recognize over a billion different shapes and objects. It can identify new objects and images it hasn’t seen before without needing extra training. By analyzing aerial images, like those taken by drones, this tool can detect sidewalks, crosswalks, roads, and other key features. It then uses this information to create detailed pedestrian maps automatically, making navigation easier and more accessible for wheelchair users.

3. We developed an adaptive routing algorithm which is designed to make rides more convenient. It starts by checking if the pickup and drop-off (PUDO) locations are within the service area of a single transportation provider. If they are, the system selects the best pick-up and drop-off points to reduce travel and waiting times. It then connects with a service platform used by the local microtransit operator to reserve a vehicle for the ride and provide estimated travel and wait times to the passenger. Based on this information, the passenger can choose from flexible ride options, a door-to-door service, or decide to decline the ride.

4. Our educational efforts created programs that combine research and teaching to focus on human-centered artificial intelligence (AI) and its use in mobility and transportation. Specifically, we launched a new MS concentrations on AI and a new graduate certificate program in mobility. While many similar programs have been launched across the country, our program is unique because it emphasizes collaboration across different fields. This interdisciplinary approach ensures we deliver innovative solutions and maximize the learning experience for our students and enhance workforce training. 


Last Modified: 12/17/2024
Modified by: Dongxiao Zhu

Images (1 of )
  • The accessible and inaccessible PUDO locations. Rider has access to both whereas driver only has access to orange locations due to the major intersection

    The accessible and inaccessible PickUp and DropOff (PUDO) locations.
  • People with disabilities are 38% more likely to be unemployed than persons without disabilities
    Microboost team
    Creative Commons
    Dongxiao Zhu
    Unemployment Rate
  • MicroBoost?s architecture. 1) the user interface to submit and select rides as well as receive ride updates, 2) easy access to the necessary wayfinding service, 3) algorithms to assess accessibility of flexible PUDO and (4) API to communicate with the SaaS.
    MicroBoost team
    Creative Commons
    Dongxiao Zhu
    MicroBoost Architecture.
